title: 108_s1949
content: The "Return of Talent Act" establishes a program for temporary absence of individuals participating in the return of talent program under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Return of Talent Program allows eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship to contribute to post-conflict reconstruction activities for up to 24 months. Family members can accompany the alien, and the Secretary of Homeland Security may grant extensions. The Return of Talent Program allows eligible aliens to temporarily return to their country of citizenship for up to 24 months to contribute to post-conflict reconstruction efforts. The Secretary of Homeland Security can extend this period if necessary. Family members accompanying the immigrant will be considered physically present and residing in the United States for naturalization purposes during their participation in the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, shall oversee and enforce the requirements of this section. SEC. 3. ELIGIBLE IMMIGRANTS. 317A. Temporary absence of persons participating in the Return of Talent Program. Section 101(a)(27) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category (N) for immigrants who are lawful permanent residents in the U.S., willing to contribute to post-conflict reconstruction in their home country, and meet criteria set by the Secretary of State and Secretary of Homeland Security. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category for immigrants who are citizens of countries where the US Armed Forces or UN peacekeeping operations have been involved in the past 10 years. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report to Congress within 24 months of this Act's enactment, detailing the countries of citizenship of Return of Talent Program participants, post-conflict reconstruction efforts impacted by the program, and any other relevant information. Additionally, within 6 months of enactment, regulations must be established to implement the Act. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services for fiscal years 2004 and 2005 to implement the Act.
